New Records: Jake Irvin's 1.16 ERA against the Atlanta Braves is the lowest mark by a pitcher in Nationals history (2005-present) with at least three starts vs. the Braves in a single season.
Key Match Events: Jake Irvin held the Atlanta Braves hitless for 5 2/3 innings, and then gave up two hits in the sixth inning, including a 109.9 mph double to Michael Harris II.
Irvin faced the minimum by getting Marcell Ozuna to ground into an inning-ending double play in the fourth inning.
Irvin stayed locked in as he faced the Braves' order a second time, getting Sean Murphy to line out to left field to avoid any damage.
Pre-Game Insights: Manager Dave Martinez said that Jake Irvin has been good, especially against the Braves, and that he attacks the strike zone, gets quick outs, and the Braves don't see it very well.
Post-Match Reflections: Irvin said that he tried to block out the no-hit bid and focus on attacking the strike zone and staying in the zone for the focus of the week and the focus of the start.
Miscellaneous Highlights: The game plan worked smoothly to overcome Irvin's previous outing, when he allowed six runs over five innings against the Pirates.
Irvin's fastball reached 96.6 mph and averaged 94, and he delivered a pitch mix of 48 four-seam fastballs, 25 sinkers, 10 curveballs, and one cutter.
Others: Irvin completed the season with a 2-0 record and a 1.16 ERA against the Braves, and the Nats went 8-5 on the season against the Braves.
